oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Governor Carey and General Gerald C. Kelleher
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Governor Hugh L. Carey pays off a World War II-era bet to General Gerald C. Kelleher. Governor Carey and General Kelleher were in the army together, in the 415th Infantry, 104th Division.;In 1945, they made a bet on who would reach Nazi-occupied Cologne first. They wagered a case of beer and a steak dinner. The Governor paid the General back with 11 cases of beer, and a map of the area in Germany. There was also a reception with other members of the 104th division. Of General Kelleher, Governor Carey said he was &quot;the finest soldier I ever met in the uniform of the U.S. Army.&quot;;They are at the Executive Mansion in Albany.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: New York (State). Governor.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Governor Carey at the Olympic Opening Ceremonies (4 of 4)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Looking out over the Olympic opening ceremonies are Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Governor Hugh L. Carey, an unidentified man, and Vice President Walter Mondale.;The Governor delivered the opening remarks for the games, stating, &quot;We New Yorkers are honored to host these games and to contribute to their success.&quot;;The Governor also gave a challenge to the athletes: &quot;To the athletes gathered here I offer the challenge of our State motto: &#39;Excelsior&#39;- ever higher. May all the records fall before your skill and prowess. May you perform to the full measure of your talents and achieve the recognition and reward your years of discipline and training deserve.&quot;;The 1980 Winter Olympics took place from February 13-February 24, in Lake Placid, New York.

May you perform to the full measure of your talents and achieve the recognition and reward your years of discipline and training deserve.&quot;;The 1980 Winter Olympics took place from February 13-February 24, in Lake Placid, New York.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Governor Carey Meeting with Seneca Indian Leaders
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Governor Hugh L. Carey meets with leaders of the Seneca Indian tribes to discuss land that was needed for the completion of a Southern Tier Expressway that would travel through part of the Seneca tribe's land. The meeting took place in the Red Room of the Executive Chamber of the Capitol Building. At the head of the table is Governor Carey, and to his immediate left is the Assistant Commissioner of the Department of Transportation William Hennessey. To his immediate right is President of the Seneca Indian Nation Robert C. Hoag.;Also in attendence at the meeting were Barry Parker, Wayne Abrams, Maurice John, and Arthur Lazarus.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A group of officials and family members listen to Governor Carey's budget briefing for the press in the Red Room of the Executive Chamber in the Capitol Building.;Seated, left to right: Warren M. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View of the South Mall model from the northwest
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of the South Mall model, from the northwest showing the Arch of Freedom in the right background, with the State Library and Archives flanking the curved Arch.&nbsp; The large base platform for all three structures contains the new State Museum.&nbsp; The 43-story Office Tower rises from the pedestrian mall area.&nbsp; The bowl-shaped structure to the left of the Office Tower is the meetings center.&nbsp; In the foreground are the four 19-story Agency buildings. Nore the road system extending to the west of the plaza.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View of the South Mall model from the southwest
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of the South Mall model, from the southwest showing the Arch of Freedom in the right foreground, with the State Library and SArchies flanking the curved Arch.&nbsp; The large base platform for all three structures comtains the new State Museum.&nbsp; At center is the 43-story Office Tower rising from the pedestrian mall area.&nbsp; The bowl-shaped structure immediately to the left of the Office Tower is the meetings center, with the existing state capitol just to the left.&nbsp; At the far left are two of the four 19-story Agency buildings.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: New York State's Executive Mansion
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Shown here is the Executive Mansion of New York State. Built in 1856, 138 Eagle Street has been used as the Governor’s Albany residence since 1875. Averell Harriman is to the left.;DeSapio, the head of the politically powerful Tammany Hall, served as Secretary of State from 1955-1959.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Victory Celebration on Election Night at the Biltmore Hotel, New York City
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Victory celebration for the election of Averell Harriman as governor of New York, 1954. Harriman defeated Irving Ives, the protege of outgoing governor Thomas Dewey. The celebration was held at the Biltmore Hotel in New York City. Harriman, in front of microphones, raised the arms of his wife Marie and New York City mayor Robert F. Wagner, Jr., who ran on the same Democratic ticket as Harriman.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hugh L. Carey at Madison Square Garden
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hugh L. Carey (right) is shown at Madison Square Garden for a fundraising rally while he was campaigning for Governor. His sons Thomas and Kevin (yawning) are shown with him. Seated behind the Careys are former Governor Averell Harriman and his wife Pamela Churchill Harriman.;New York City Mayor Abraham Beame, Robert Wagner, and John Lindsay also attended. Frank Sinatra and Allan King were headliners at the rally.;Photograph taken by Jerry Engel, New York Post. Copyright held by The New York Post.

We begin that war here in Bryant Park, a small piece of New York State which pushers claim belongs to them. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Arthur Wicks, raising right hand, being sworn in as Lieutenant Governor by a judge, 1953. Wicks was been the Majority Leader of the State Senate, and served simultaneously as Lieutenant Governor under Gov. Thomas E. Dewey. Shortly after taking this office, Dewey forced Wicks to resign both offices after his repeated visits to convicted labor leader Joseph Fay were publicized.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Governor Carey waves at Airplane
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Governor Hugh L. Carey waves at the airplane that is carrying recently released American hostages from Iran, as it arrives at Stewart Air Force Base, in Newburgh, New York.;52 hostages were held in the U.S. Embassy in Iran for 444 days from November 4, 1979 until January 20, 1981, in what was referred to as the Iran Hostage Crisis.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Iran Hostages Return Home
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Governor Hugh Carey at Stewart Air Force Base in Newburgh, greeting American hostages who had been held in Iran from 1979-1981. Carey was the first public official to welcome them back to the United States. In this photograph Carey greets former hostage Katherine Koob.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: New York (State). Governor.
